column4: World Bank - Income after tax or consumption
column7: The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column2: Income or consumption share of the top 10%
column4: World Bank - Income after tax or consumption
column7: This is the income or consumption of the richest decile (tenth of the population) as a share of total income or consumption.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column4: World Bank - Income after tax or consumption
column7: P90 and P10 are the levels of income or consumption below which 90% and 10% of the population live, respectively. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column4: World Bank - Income after tax or consumption
column7: The P90/P50 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the richest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that someone just falling in the richest tenth of the population has twice the median income or consumption.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column4: World Bank - Income after tax or consumption
column7: The P50/P10 ratio measures the degree of inequality within the poorest half of the population. A ratio of 2 means that the median income or consumption is two times higher than that of someone just falling in the poorest tenth of the population.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column4: World Bank - Income after tax or consumption
column7: The Palma ratio is the share of total income or consumption of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column2: Relative poverty: Share of people below 50% of the median
column4: World Bank - Income after tax or consumption
column5: Share in relative poverty (< 50% of the median)
column7: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes â€“ in this case set at 50% of the median income or consumption.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column5:
The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the richest 10% (Pretax national income) (WID)
column5:
This is the income of the richest 10% as a share of total income.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the bottom 50% (Pretax national income) (WID)
column5:
This is the income of the poorest 50% as a share of total income.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the richest 1% (Pretax national income) (WID)
column5:
This is the income of the richest 1% as a share of total income.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the richest 0.1% (Pretax national income) (WID)
column5:
This is the income of the richest 0.1% as a share of total income.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the richest 0.01% (Pretax national income) (WID)
column5:
This is the income of the richest 0.01% as a share of total income.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

column2: Income share of the richest 0.001% (Pretax national income) (WID)
column5:
This is the income of the richest 0.001% as a share of total income.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

P90 is the the level of income below which 90% of the population lives. P10 is the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality that indicates the gap between the richest and poorest tenth of the population. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

P90 is the the level of income above which 10% of the population lives. P50 is the median â€“ the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the top half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone in the middle of the distribution would need to be in order to be counted in the richest tenth.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

P50 is the median â€“ the level of income below which 50% of the population lives. P10 is the the level of income below which 10% of the population lives. This variable gives the ratio of the two. It is a measure of inequality within the bottom half of the distribution. It tells you how many times richer someone just in the the poorest tenth would need to be in order to be reach the median.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.

The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality: it is the share of total income of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.

This is pretax national income. Income here is measured before the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits. Income is also measured after payment of public and private pensions.
